questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with a history of epistaxis and recurrent rectal bleeding. The parents also reported a history of bleeding from the umbilicus since birth. Laboratory investigations revealed normal prothrombin time (PT), normal thrombin time, normal activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), normal platelet count, and normal function. Urea clot solubility test was positive. What is the most likely deficient factor in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Factor XIII

 

Explanation:

The given clinical feature is characteristic of Factor XIII (FXIII) deficiency / Laki lorand factor deficiency. It is a rare bleeding disorder that presents with symptoms spanning from delayed umbilical cord separation to intracranial hemorrhage.

  • FXIII plays a pivotal role in stabilizing clots and facilitating the cross-linking of the fibrin polymer, thereby ensuring effective hemostasis
  • The acquired FXIII deficiency typically arises from factors such as hyperconsumption, hemodilution, and decreased synthesis and is more prevalent than the congenital form.
  • In rare instances, individuals with acquired FXIII deficiency may generate autoantibodies targeting FXIII subunits.


Factor XI deficiency (Option B) and Factor XII deficiency (Option D) causes prolonged Activated partial prothrombin time (aPTT) but Prothrombin time (PT) will be normal.


Factor X deficiency (Option C) causes both prolonged Prothrombin time (PT) and

Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

questions.text: A child presented with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. What is the enzyme deficiency producing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Glucocerebrosidase:

  • A child presented with anemia, mental r*etardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance. The enzyme deficiency producing this condition is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hexosaminidase-A:

  • This enzyme deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which is characterized by progressive neurological degeneration, but it does not typically present with the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow or the specific combination of symptoms described (anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, hepatosplenomegaly).

Option B - Iduronate 2-sulphatase:

  • Deficiency of this enzyme is associated with Hunter syndrome, a type of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS II). This condition can cause developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and hepatosplenomegaly but does not typically present with the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow.

Option C - Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase:

  • Deficiency in this enzyme leads to G6PD deficiency, which can cause hemolytic anemia but does not typically cause the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance in bone marrow or the combination of symptoms described.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, a hemoglobin level of 7 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 50,000 cells/cu.mm, and petechiae and purpura. What is the recommended drug treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vincristine + Prednisolone:

  • This combination is commonly used as part of the treatment regimen for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Vincristine is a chemotherapy agent that inhibits cell division, and Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that helps reduce inflammation and has antitumor effects. This option is appropriate if the child's symptoms are indicative of ALL, as the high WBC count and symptoms like hepatosplenomegaly and purpura are consistent with leukemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – IVIG:

  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used for treating immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and other conditions involving immune-mediated platelet destruction. While IVIG can be beneficial in conditions with bleeding tendencies, it is not typically used as the primary treatment for leukemia.

Option C - L-Asparaginase + Prednisolone:

  • L-Asparaginase is an enzyme used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) as part of a chemotherapy regimen. It works by depleting asparagine, an amino acid necessary for leukemia cell survival. Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used to enhance the effects of chemotherapy and reduce inflammation. This combination is appropriate for treating ALL, but without additional context, it’s less specific than Vincristine + Prednisolone in a classic ALL regimen.

Option D - Daunorubicin + Prednisolone:

  • Daunorubicin is a chemotherapy drug used primarily in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and sometimes in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used to support chemotherapy treatment. This combination is generally used for AML rather than ALL.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased urine bilirubin

Explanation:

In Rh incompatibility, maternal antibodies destroy fetal Rh-positive RBCs, leading to hemolysis and excessive unconjugated bilirubin (Option A).

  • Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, preventing urinary excretion. Instead, intestinal bacteria convert it to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are eliminated in stool. (Options B & D)
  • Urine bilirubin consists of conjugated bilirubin, which requires hepatic processing. However, in Rh incompatibility, the liver is overwhelmed, leading to predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and no significant increase in urine bilirubin.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigations is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Globin gene sequencing

Explanation:

In this case, the presence of target cells and a history of repeated blood transfusions suggests a possible hemoglobinopathy, such as thalassemia or sickle cell disease.

  • Globin gene sequencing is a molecular diagnostic test that can identify specific mutations or genetic alterations in the globin genes.

  • By sequencing the globin genes, such as the alpha and beta globin genes, it is possible to identify the specific genetic abnormality responsible for the hemoglobinopathy.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Option A) is a commonly used method to measure the different types of hemoglobin and their variants in the blood. While HPLC can help in identifying abnormal hemoglobin variants, it may not provide a definitive diagnosis of the underlying genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy.

Estimating ferritin levels (Option B) can provide information about the iron stores in the body but may not directly help in diagnosing the underlying cause of the anemia or the specific genetic abnormality causing the hemoglobinopathy.

While bone marrow examination (Option C) can provide valuable information about the cells in the bone marrow, it may not always be necessary for the definitive diagnosis of hemoglobinopathy

questions.text: A patient has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, a diagnosis of a mild case of ITP is made. How will you manage the patient?

choices.text: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Education, counseling, and watchful expectancy

 

Explanation:

In a patient with mild ITP who has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis but minimal interference with daily activities, the preferred approach is watchful expectancy.

  • Most cases of mild ITP in children resolve spontaneously without treatment.
  • Regular follow-up visits can help assess the progression of the disease and determine the need for intervention if symptoms worsen or if there is an increase in bleeding risk.
  • The observation period involves providing education and counseling to the patient and closely monitoring platelet counts and symptoms over time.
     

Management of Immune thrombocytopenic purpura in children

Based on platelet count:

  • Platelet Count >30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding- Monitor closely
  • Platelet Count < 30,000 cells/μL + No severe bleeding + Platelet Count ≥ 5,000 cells/μL: Glucocorticoids (e.g., Prednisone, Dexamethasone)
  • Platelet Count < 5,000 cells/μL or Severe Bleeding: i.v.i.g.+ Glucocorticoids

Other modalities:

 
  • Immediate Need to Raise Platelet Count like surgery or trauma- Platelet Transfusion
  • Persistent or Severe Cases- Monitor with intermittent i.v.i.g.
  • If necessary, consider Splenectomy

Alternative Medications:
  • Anti-CD20 Antibody: Rituximab
  • TPO Receptor Agonists: Romiplostim, Eltrombopag

 

Short course corticosteroid therapy (Option A) is not indicated as the first-line treatment for mild ITP with minimal symptoms. While corticosteroids like prednisone are effective, their side effects outweigh the benefits in mild cases. Corticosteroids are typically reserved for cases with more severe thrombocytopenia or significant bleeding risk.

Intravenous anti-D administration (Option B) is an intervention reserved for Rh-positive patients with more severe ITP requiring rapid platelet count elevation. In mild cases with minimal symptoms, this aggressive approach is unnecessary and carries potential risks.

A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (Option C) represents an aggressive and costly intervention that is not warranted in mild ITP cases. IVIG is typically reserved for severe cases with significant bleeding risk or very low platelet counts (<5,000/μL).

Correct Option. B

  • Leukemia: Leukemia is a type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood. It involves the abnormal production of white blood cells, which can interfere with the normal functioning of red blood cells and platelets. The two main types of leukemia in children are acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Symptoms can include fatigue, pale skin, frequent infections, easy bruising or bleeding, bone pain, swollen lymph nodes, and weight loss. Treatment for leukemia typically involves chemotherapy, sometimes combined with radiation therapy and stem cell transplantation.

Incorrect options 

Option A) Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a rare form of eye cancer that primarily affects young children. It develops in the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. Retinoblastoma may be hereditary or sporadic (non-hereditary). The most common sign is the presence of a white pupil or a noticeable difference in the color of the pupil between the two eyes. Other symptoms may include strabismus (crossed or misaligned eyes), poor vision, and eye pain. Treatment options include chemotherapy, radiation therapy, cryotherapy (freezing the tumor), and surgical removal of the affected eye.

Option C) Wilms tumor: Wilms tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children. It usually occurs in children aged 3 to 4 years. The most common sign is the presence of a painless abdominal mass or swelling. Other symptoms may include abdominal pain, fever, and blood in the urine. Treatment involves surgical removal of the tumor, followed by chemotherapy and sometimes radiation therapy. The prognosis for Wilms tumor is generally favorable, with high survival rates.

Option D) Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is a cancer that develops from immature nerve cells, primarily affecting children aged 5 years or younger. It usually arises in the adrenal glands (located on top of the kidneys) or in nerve tissue along the spine, chest, abdomen, or pelvis. Neuroblastoma may cause various symptoms depending on the location and extent of the tumor, such as abdominal pain, a palpable mass, bone pain, fever, weight loss, and changes in bowel or bladder function. Treatment options include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. The prognosis for neuroblastoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the age at diagnosis, stage of the disease, and genetic characteristics.

questions.text: A child presents with petechiae, purpura, and a platelet count of 10,000/µL. Bone marrow examination reveals increased megakaryocytes.Which of the following is the drug of choice (DOC) for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option c) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

Explanation

This clinical presentation (petechiae, purpura, platelet count of 10,000/µL, and increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow) is characteristic of Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), also previously known as Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura. In ITP, the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys platelets, leading to a low platelet count. The bone marrow, in an attempt to compensate for the rapid destruction, produces more megakaryocytes (the precursor cells to platelets), which is why their number is increased on bone marrow examination.

  • Bone marrow transplant (Option A ruled out): This is a very aggressive and high-risk procedure. It is not a first-line treatment for ITP. It might be considered in very rare, refractory cases of severe, chronic ITP that haven't responded to multiple other treatments, but it's far from the drug of choice.
  • Methotrexate (Option B ruled out): This is an immunosuppressant and chemotherapy agent. While some immunosuppressants might be used in refractory chronic ITP (e.g., rituximab, cyclosporine, azathioprine), methotrexate is not a standard first-line drug of choice for acute severe ITP in children.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)(Option C): This is a primary drug of choice for acute, severe ITP, especially when a rapid increase in platelet count is desired due to significant bleeding or very low counts. It's often used alongside or as an alternative to corticosteroids.
  • Aspirin (Option D ruled out) Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet function. Giving aspirin to a patient with a critically low platelet count and bleeding (petechiae, purpura) would be highly contraindicated as it would worsen bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sickle cell anemia: Sickle cell is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Incorrect Options - A, C, and D are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is experiencing symptoms that indicate anemia, but they are not specific. The examination of a sample of blood under a microscope reveals the presence of target cells. The child also has a low level of hemoglobin (6 gm%) and exhibits a picture of microcytic hypochromic. Additionally, there is a positive family history of this condition. The next step in the diagnostic process is to conduct which investigation?

choices.text: Newborn screening for sickle cell disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hb Electrophoresis:

  • Hb electrophoresis is a laboratory test used to identify and quantify the different types of hemoglobin in the blood.
  • It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of hemoglobinopathies, including thalassemias and sickle cell disease.
  • In the case of a 2-year-old child presenting with microcytic hypochromic anemia, a positive family history, and target cells on the peripheral smear, Hb electrophoresis is a crucial investigation to assess for the presence of any abnormal hemoglobin variants or thalassemias.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Newborn screening for sickle cell disease:

  • It is a test used to screen newborns for sickle cell disease.
  • It is not typically used as a diagnostic test for anemia in a 2-year-old child presenting with nonspecific symptoms.

Option B - HbA1c estimation: HbA1c is a blood test used primarily for the diagnosis and management of diabetes.

Option D - Osmotic fragility test:

  • The osmotic fragility test is a laboratory test that measures the susceptibility of red blood cells to burst when exposed to changes in osmotic pressure.
  • It is primarily used to diagnose and monitor certain types of hereditary red blood cell disorders, such as hereditary spherocytosis.
  • While it can be useful in specific cases of hemolytic anemias, it is not the most appropriate next investigation in this case, as the clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings suggest a microcytic hypochromic anemia.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) indicates an unfavorable prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Age > 10 years:

  • Children older than 10 years of age have a higher risk of relapse and poorer outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Leukocyte count < 50,000/mm3:

  • A lower leukocyte count is associated with a more favorable prognosis in ALL.
  • High leukocyte counts at diagnosis indicate a higher tumor burden and are considered a poor prognostic factor.

Option C: Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy, which refers to the presence of more than the normal number of chromosomes in leukemic cells, is associated with a favorable prognosis in pediatric ALL.

Option D: Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, and 17: Trisomies involving chromosomes 4, 10, and 17 are often observed in pediatric ALL and are associated with a more favorable prognosis.

questions.text: What is the viral infection that can lead to temporary aplastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Parvovirus B-19

  • Parvovirus B-19 is known to cause a transient aplastic crisis, which is a temporary suppression of red blood cell production in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders, such as sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Parvovirus B-19 infects erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, leading to their destruction and subsequent reduction in red blood cell production.

Incorrect Options - A, B, and D do not cause temporary aplastic anemia.
